intro: Malus sylvestris var. paradisiaca, commonly known as the paradise apple tree, is a variant of the common crabapple. It is characterized by its ornamental flowers and small, edible fruits that are often used in culinary applications. The plant is native to Central Asia and thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soil. It typically grows to a height of 5–10 meters and features a rounded, compact form. Its foliage turns vibrant shades of red and orange in the fall, adding to its ornamental value.
